content.question: The distribution of body temperature for healthy adults is approximately normal with mean <math alttext="98.2 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>98.2</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math> and standard deviation <math alttext="0.7 degree Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.7</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math>. Based on the description of the distribution, which of the following statements CANNOT be supported?

choices.label: More than <math alttext="95%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of healthy adults have a body temperature greater than <math alttext="96.8 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>96.8</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math>.
The first quartile of the distribution of healthy adults’ body temperature is less than <math alttext="97.5 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>97.5</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math>.

Approximately <math alttext="50%" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of healthy adults have a body temperature greater than <math alttext="98.2 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>98.2</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math>.

Approximately <math alttext="95%" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of healthy adults have a body temperature between <math alttext="96.8 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>96.8</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math> and <math alttext="99.6 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>99.6</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math>.

A body temperature of <math alttext="100.3 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>100.3</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math> or more would occur in less than <math alttext="2%" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of healthy adults.

content.answer: The first quartile of the distribution of healthy adults’ body temperature is less than <math alttext="97.5 degrees Fahrenheit" overflow="scroll"><mn>97.5</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>F</mtext></math>.

skill.text: Skill 2.D: Compare distributions or relative positions of points within a distribution.
